In Literary Tibetan, the adversative connective སྟེ་ “but” has several variants according to the last letter of the preceding syllable.

  • སྟེ་ is used after ག་ ང་ བ་ མ་ འ་ and vowels
  • དེ་ is used after ད་
  • ཏེ་ is used after ན་ ར་ ལ་ ས་ and the ད་དྲག་

In speech, the three are all pronounced de.

This particle has a range of functions in Literary Tibetan. In the spoken language, by contrast, it is used only to introduce an opposition between two phrases or a concession, and may be translated by “but” or “although.”

The particle སྟེ་ is only used after certain auxiliaries. It usually appears in the following combinations: ཡོད་དེ་, ཡོད་རེད་དེ་, འདུག་སྟེ་, ཡིན་ཏེ་, རེད་ཏེ་.

  • འདྲ་པོ་རེད་དེ་གཅིག་པ་རང་མ་རེད། “Even though they’re similar, they’re not quite identical.”
  • ཁོང་ལ་དངུལ་ཡོད་རེད་དེ། བེད་སྤྱོད་བཏང་གི་ཡོད་མ་རེད། “He has money but he doesn’t use it.”
  • སྐད་ཡག་པོ་འདུག་སྟེ་གཞས་བཏང་གི་མི་འདུག “Although she has a nice voice, she doesn’t sing.”
